[h1]else Statements[/h1]

An [b]else [/b]statement follows an [b]if[/b] statement, and contains code that is called when the if statement evaluates to [b]False[/b]. 
As with [b]if[/b] statements, the code inside the block should be indented.[code format="py" codeId="300"]x = 4
[b]if[/b] x == 5:
   print("Yes")
[b]else:[/b]
   print("No")[/code]
[b]Result: [/b] [code format="raw" ]>>> 
No
>>>[/code]

quizzes.textContent:
[h1]else Statements[/h1]

You can chain [b]if[/b] and [b]else[/b] statements to determine which option in a series of possibilities is true.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="301"]num = 7
[b]if[/b] num == 5:
  print("Number is 5")
[b]else[/b]: 
  [b]if [/b]num == 11:
    print("Number is 11")
  [b]else[/b]:
    [b]if[/b] num == 7:
      print("Number is 7")
    [b]else[/b]: 
      print("Number isn't 5, 11 or 7")[/code]
[b]Result:  [/b][code format="raw" ]>>>
Number is 7
>>> [/code]

quizzes.question: A shorter option for an "else if" statement is:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]elif Statements[/h1]

The [b]elif ([/b]short for else if) statement is a shortcut to use when chaining [b]if[/b] and [b]else [/b]statements.
A series of [b]if elif[/b] statements can have a final [b]else [/b]block, which is called if none of the [b]if[/b] or [b]elif [/b]expressions is True.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="302"]num = 7
[b]if[/b] num == 5:
   print("Number is 5")
[b]elif [/b]num == 11:
   print("Number is 11")
[b]elif [/b]num == 7:
   print("Number is 7")
[b]else:[/b]
   print("Number isn't 5, 11 or 7")[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
Number is 7
>>>[/code]
[note]In other programming languages, equivalents to the [b]elif [/b]statement have varying names, including [b]else if[/b], [b]elseif [/b]or [b]elsif[/b].[/note]
